Study Title: Duration of Device-Based Fever Prevention after Cardiac Arrest.
Conclusion: Active device-based fever prevention for 36 or 72 hours after cardiac arrest did not result in significantly different percentages of patients dying or having severe disability or coma.
Primary Outcome: Death from any cause or hospital discharge with a Cerebral Performance Category of 3 or 4 within 90 days after randomization
Results for the Primary Outcome: 32.3% in the 36-hour group and 33.6% in the 72-hour group (hazard ratio, 0.99; 95% confidence interval, 0.77 to 1.26; P = 0.70)
Comparator: device-based temperature control targeting 36degC for 24 hours followed by targeting of 37degC for either 12 or 48 hours

Study Title: Chlorthalidone vs. Hydrochlorothiazide for Hypertension-Cardiovascular Events.
Conclusion: There was no difference in the occurrence of major cardiovascular outcome events or non-cancer-related deaths between patients who received chlorthalidone and patients who received hydrochlorothiazide.
Primary Outcome: Composite of nonfatal myocardial infarction, stroke, heart failure resulting in hospitalization, urgent coronary revascularization for unstable angina, and non-cancer-related death
Results for the Primary Outcome: Hazard ratio, 1.04; 95% confidence interval, 0.94 to 1.16; P = 0.45
Comparator: Patients receiving hydrochlorothiazide vs. patients receiving chlorthalidone

Study Title: Zanubrutinib or Ibrutinib in Relapsed or Refractory Chronic Lymphocytic Leukemia.
Conclusion: Patients taking zanubrutinib had a significantly longer progression-free survival than those taking ibrutinib.
Results for the Primary Outcome: The median progression-free survival was not reached in the zanubrutinib arm and was 24.9 months in the ibrutinib arm (hazard ratio 0.41; 95% confidence interval 0.29-0.59; P < 0.0001).

Study Title: Intravenous ferric derisomaltose in patients with heart failure and iron deficiency in the UK (IRONMAN): an investigator-initiated, prospective, randomised, open-label, blinded-endpoint trial.
Conclusion: Intravenous ferric derisomaltose administration was associated with a lower risk of hospital admissions for heart failure and cardiovascular death in patients with heart failure, reduced left vent
Primary Outcome: Recurrent hospital admissions for heart failure and cardiovascular death
Results for the Primary Outcome: 336 primary endpoints (22.4 per 100 patient-years) occurred in the ferric derisomaltose group and 411 (27.5 per 100 patient-years) occurred in the usual care group (rate ratio [RR] 0.82 [95% CI 0.66 to 1.02]; p=0.070). In the COVID-19 analysis, 210 primary endpoints (22.3 per 100 patient-years) occurred in the ferric derisomaltose group compared with 280 (29.3 per 100 patient-years) in the usual care group (RR 0.76 [95% CI 0.58 to 1.00]; p=0.047).
Blinding: Open label, with masked adjudication of the outcomes
Comparator: Intravenous ferric derisomaltose vs. usual care

Study Title: Empagliflozin in Patients with Chronic Kidney Disease.
Conclusion: Empagliflozin therapy led to a lower risk of progression of kidney disease or death from cardiovascular causes than placebo in patients with chronic kidney disease who were at risk for disease progression.
Primary Outcome: Progression of kidney disease or death from cardiovascular causes
Results for the Primary Outcome: 13.1% of patients in the empagliflozin group and 16.9% of patients in the placebo group experienced progression of kidney disease or death from cardiovascular causes (hazard ratio, 0.72; 95% confidence interval [CI], 0.64 to 0.82; P<0.001).
Comparator: empagliflozin (10 mg once daily) vs. matching placebo

Study Title: Progression of Atrial Fibrillation after Cryoablation or Drug Therapy.
Conclusion: Initial treatment of paroxysmal atrial fibrillation with catheter cryoballoon ablation was associated with a lower incidence of persistent atrial fibrillation or recurrent atrial tachyarrhythmia than initial use of antiarrhythmic drugs.
Primary Outcome: Incidence of persistent atrial fibrillation or recurrent atrial tachyarrhythmia
Results for the Primary Outcome: 3 patients (1.9%) in the ablation group had an episode of persistent atrial fibrillation, as compared with 11 patients (7.4%) in the antiarrhythmic drug group (hazard ratio, 0.25; 95% confidence interval [CI], 0.09 to 0.70).
Comparator: Ablation group (154 patients) and antiarrhythmic drug group (149 patients)

Study Title: Surgery or Endovascular Therapy for Chronic Limb-Threatening Ischemia.
Conclusion: Among patients with CLTI who had an adequate great saphenous vein for surgical revascularization (cohort 1), the incidence of a major adverse limb event or death was significantly lower in the surgical group than in the endovascular group. Among the patients who lacked an adequate saphenous vein conduit (cohort 2), the outcomes in the two groups were similar.
Primary Outcome: Composite of a major adverse limb event or death from any cause
Results for the Primary Outcome: 42.8% in the surgical group and 47.7% in the endovascular group (hazard ratio, 0.79; 95% CI, 0.58 to 1.06; P = 0.12).

Study Title: Trial of an Intervention to Improve Acute Heart Failure Outcomes.
Primary Outcome: Composite of death from any cause or hospitalization for cardiovascular causes within 30 days after presentation and the composite outcome within 20 months
Results for the Primary Outcome: Within 30 days, death from any cause or hospitalization for cardiovascular causes occurred in 301 patients (12.1%) who were enrolled during the intervention phase and in 430 patients (14.5%) who were enrolled during the control phase (adjusted hazard ratio, 0.88; 95% confidence interval [CI], 0.78 to 0.99; P = 0.04). Within 20 months, the cumulative incidence of primary-outcome events was 54.4% (95% CI, 48.6 to 59.9) among patients who were enrolled during the intervention phase and 56.2% (95% CI, 54.2 to 58.1) among patients who were enrolled during the control phase (adjusted hazard ratio, 0.95; 95
Comparator: Control phase (usual care) vs. intervention phase (point-of-care algorithm to stratify patients with acute heart failure according to the risk of death)

Study Title: Methylprednisolone for Heart Surgery in Infants - A Randomized, Controlled Trial.
Conclusion: Prophylactic use of methylprednisolone did not significantly reduce the likelihood of a worse outcome and was associated with postoperative development of hyperglycemia warranting insulin in a higher percentage of infants than placebo.
Primary Outcome: Ranked composite of death, heart transplantation, or any of 13 major complications
Results for the Primary Outcome: Adjusted odds ratio of 0.86 (95% CI, 0.71 to 1.05; P = 0.14)
